South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Sudan Express Mail Service
div.p: Three days to Khartoum

By KHEDIVIAL MAIL EXPRESS S.S. "PRINCE ABBAS" and "EL KAHIRA" and SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS "Trains de Luxe." DEPARTURES from SUEZ DOCKS every WEDNESDAY 5 p.m. after arrival of 11 a.m. Train from Cairo, with Through Carriages to alongside steamer. Special Sudan Government Train de Luxe with Sleeping and Dining Cars, awaits steamer's arrival at PORT SUDAN, FRIDAY EVENINGS, arriving KHARTOUM 8 p.m. SATURDAYS. RETURNING from KHARTOUM, the Special Train leaves TUESDAYS 9.15 p.m. arriving alongside steamer at PORT SUDAN WEDNESDAY EVENINGS. Steamer is timed to reach SUEZ SATURDAYS, to connect with 5.40 p.m. train to Cairo. Further particulars may be obtained from any of KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE'S Agencies or from Principal Tourist Agencies by whom Circular Tickets are issued to Khartoum by the Nile, returning by Red Sea Express Service or Vice-Versa.

div.head: Egypt and the Sudan
div.p: Commenting upon Sir Eldon Gorst's visit to the Sudan the Standard" says :

Sir Eldon Gorst, who is returning to Cairo after bis brief tour of inspection in the Sudan, bas bad an opportunity of seeing something of the latest developments of that interesting territory. It is perhaps needless to say that the high political significance attributed to the visit by the anti-English journalists of Cairo exists only in the imagination of those ingenious persons. These astute critics, who bave lately been endeavouring to persuade their readers that the Sudan is a crushing and onprofitable burden upon Egypt, have been suggesting that Sir Eldon will inaugurate an ora of drastic economies for the upper country. Some of them even went so far as to hint that in this enterprise the British Consul-General was to receive the active assistance of the Under Secretary for the Colonies, and that the two statesmen would have an opportunity of conferring on these matters on the Upper Nile. Nothing of course could be more ridiculous. Neither Egypt nor the Sudan comes, in the smallest de ree, within the Under-Secretary's "sphere of influence." At Khartum Mr. Winston Churchill was received with the courtesy which in that pleasant and hospitable capital is often extended even to less distinguished guests; but his visit had no more official character than that of any other traveller who happened to be passing through on his way down from the equatorial regions, and both Mr. Churchill and his hosts took care to do nothing which could lead to misconception on this point. As a fact, the Under Secretary for the Colonies bad goitted Khartum before Sir Eldon Gorst had left Cairo ; and though they passed one another on the journey they could certainly have had no facilities, even if such had been sought, for the discussion of political affairs Apart from this myth, there is no reason to suppose that any immediate change in Sudan policy is contemplated or any serious revolution in the relations, financial and orber, which link the Anglo-Egyptian condominium to the Khedivial Government. The situation, so ably sum. marised in the last of Lord Cromer's great series of Reports, is not for the present likely to be modified in its main lines. But bere, as elsewbere, Sir Eldon Gorst has been anxious to render bimself familiar with all the details of administration, not so much with the idea of correcting the work of his predecessor as of extending and amplifying it, and adapting it where necessary to exigencies which were not contemplated during the years when Lord Cromer was rebuilding the fabric of orderly administration throughout the Nile Valley.

In the Sudan, even more than in Egypt, the problem is one of developing by administiative means the resources of the country That the vast territory, in spite of its tracts of arid waste and inbospitable desert, contains the possibililies of immense agricultural wealth is the assured belief of all who know something about it. Irrigation; population, and communication are its three prime requisites. Next, of course, after that repression of rapine and violence which the Anglo-Egyptian arins have secured. The first and second of thee two great needs cannot be supplied, other difficulties apart, until progress has been made with the third. The Sudan, like the Britain of the Roman poet, has been penitus toto divisum ab urbe : too long cut oft from the stream of the world's commerce, and accessible only by the long, narrow thoroughfare that leads from the Mediterranean by the Nile sud over the cataracts and through the desert. By that difficult and devious track, on the decks of sailing boats and river steamers, and on the backs of camels, such heavy articles as machinery and building plant have been conveyed with infinite labour into the heart of tropical Africa. But for modern commeree the route is far too slow and too costly. From the beginning of our occupation of the terrirory it has been seen that the Sudan, if it is to make full use of its agricultural capacities, must be placed in direct communication with the Red Sea. During the last year and a half this aim has been achieved. The railways from the Atbara, near Berber, to Port Sudan, few miles from Snakin, is the worthy complement of the work of Lord Kitcbener and Sir Percy Girvuard when they carried the line across the desert from Wady Halfe, and so placed Khurtum in contact with Europe and the Nile Delta From the mercantile point Tof view, the Port Sudan railway, is even more valuable. Sir Eldon Gorst, whose tour in. cluded a trip over the new line and an ex amination of its outlet, can bardly fail to bave been surprised at wbat be saw. In the sbort space of two years and a half he will have found that the engiveers of the Sudan Government have bridged the old caravan route to the sea by a railway, on which one can travel in all the height of modern luxury ; and at the terwious they have laid something more than the foundation of a first-rate modern port and trading town on what thirty years ago was a stretch of uninbabited foreshore. At Port Sydan tbe Consul General saw the plans of fiue streets, squares, public buildingo; be saw in actual being quays, warehouse, steam cranes, coal lifting machinery-all the appliances of brisk and enterprising trade. Port Sudan, with its fine harbour and its open channel, navigable at all hours and in all tides, may become one of the notable commercial entrepots of the world. Sooner or later it seems inevitable that the trade of North Eyoatorial Africa must flow through its gates. Meanwhile, it has brought the Sudan into almost startling coutignity with the main centres of the world's industry and population. A passenger travelling by this route can reach Khartum eight days after leaving London, without suffering the smallest discomfort or inconvenience en route ; a load of cotton, grown on the Sudan plantation, can be raileal to the Red Sea and shipped to the docks at Salford without breaking bulk and in a space of time which will compare very favourably with the transit from most other centres for the supply of the fibre. By an audacious flank attack, the isolation of Central Africa has at length been broken down, and the results of the movement, though they may not be realised so quickly with its leaders anticipate, must oveatually be remarkable.

div.head: The Imperial Pierrots
div.p: The Imperial Pierrots are to give an entertainment in the Recreation Rooms, Kasr el Nil Barracks, on Friday evening next, Colonel Markham having kindly placed the rooms at their disposal.

div.head: Khartoum Bridge
div.p: The bridge which is in course of construction over the Blue Nile between Khartoum and Khartoum North is making exellent progress, and it is expected that the masonry will be visible above the water in a few weeks time.

div.head: St. Mary's Cairo
div.p: The services at St Mary's Church, Kasr-elDoubara, on Sunday next will be as follows: 8 am. Holy Communion 10. 30. a m. Mattins and Sertion, 6 pm. Evensong.be Rev. P. A Braithwaite, D.D., LL D, Rector, will conduct the services.

div.head: The Agricultural Bank
div.p: The issue of the remaining bonds of the Agricultural Bank of Egypt, which, we understand, has recently taken place, will afford this institution a means of removing onerous restrictions, which it bad to pursue owing to s lack of integral funds. This will now menn a contingence of the outflow of small loans, E which under present conditions will certainly be readily paght after by the fellaheen pipoc lation of Egypt.

div.head: Photographing The Sultan
div.p: A new departure was made at the Cuorban. Bairam ceremony in the Mirassin Kiosk, at Yildiz, on Wednesday, when for the first time since his session the Sultan allowed himselt to be photographed. After accepting the bomage of all the Ministers, functionaries, IG and notables, the Sultan received the con gratulations of the Ambassadors. His Majesty who appeared to be in very good bralth, obatted brightly with the latter for over an hour, and laughingly mentioned that he had four pbotographie cameras at work all through the ceremony taking anap sbots, but be feared they would prove a failure as the light was poor.

div.head: Football in Cairo
div.p: The semi-fuel of the Big Unit Shield Was played at the Khedivial Sporting Club on Wednesday afternoon, the coutesting teams N being the King Owu Scottish Borderers v. these 60 th. Rifles, and an excellent game resulted in a draw. The result of the match, can, bow.se ever bardly be taken as a fair criterion of the s respetive merits of the two teams, for the pas sing and combination of the K.O.S.B. was dis tinctly superior to that of their opponents and they had the best of the game throuxbout. The K.O.S.B. soored one goal in the first half, and taiutained their advantage until just before the call of time when the Rifles succeeded in equalizing matters.

div.head: Army of Occupation
div.p: Last Thursday a strong draft of Coldstream Guards left Southampton in the "Soudan" for Egypt, where they will join the third Battalion. Major Skeftington-Smyth was in command of the reinforcements, whose departure was attended by several officers of the Coldstream battalions remaining at home. The same boat is bringing out the 1st Battalion (Alexandra Princess of Wales's Owo) Yorkshire Regiment, the od "19th Foot,' or "Green Howards" Lieut-Col. E. M. Esso in command, and the marching out strength is 21 officers, 830 N.C.O's and men, and 89 w. men and children. One company - Capt. W.B Walker's "C" Company--three officers and 100 N.C.O's and men, has been detailed for twelve months' duty at Cyprus, after wbich it will be relieved by another company from headquarters. The battalion, which leaves Aldershot, witba very high reputation, had a hearty send off.

div.head: Lord Curzon and Parliament. SEAT IN LORDS TO BE DISPUTED.
div.p: It is reported that Lord Curzon's right to take bis sent in the House of Lords will be disputed at the opening of Parliament, because De be has failed to establish his right to vote ed at the election of representative Peers for Ireland The matter may be referred to the committee of privileges.

div.head: The Khedive
div.p: His Highness the Khedive will hold his Annual Ball at the Palace of Abdin on the 10th of February. His Highness will return to Cairo from Alexandria tomorrow.

div.head: Al Azhar (The Abdin Incident)
div.p: The unpleasant incident, to which were ferred in Tuesday's issue, apropos of the exclusion of Sheikh Rasi from the Khedive's Coreception at Abdeen Palace does n3t call for any further detailed obeervations. The ovent He was certainly regrettable in that it may CRUSO e certain amount of feeling in the great Uni versity, where, if anywhere, completo barmony should prevail. On the other hand the authorities were left to ohoice in the matter and it was undoubtedly due to the Sheikh's own want of tact that he should have brought himself into such an unpleasant position.

The reform of Al Azhar, on which this inci dent hinges, is one of the great problems apon which the Moslem world appear to be some what, divided. In all cases where religious questions are involved there will over be two parties, those who are in favour of keeping things they are, and those who desire to move with the spirit of the times. Such diver gencies necessarily lead to a great deal of bad blood for there is no more fruitfulsoil for acrimonious hostilities than the "odium theolog icum "His Highness must find himself in great difficulties in his endeavour to reconcile these conflicting elements, but no doubt in course of time with patience and his proverbial powers of persuasion be will bring the parties interest ed to remon. Personally we are not in a position to express any opinion as to the rights and wrongs of the controversy, but what we do feel strongly is that there is an immense deal of wasted power in this great theological seminary It is a thousand pities that some scheme cannot be devised whereby the New University idea cannot be merged in that of Al Athar. All Moslem education must under existing conditions bave a religious basis. Therefore it would be a fatal step, in the present backward condition of the Egyptian people, to concentrate all the elements of progress in order to found New University, thus leaving the venerable and historical Al Azhar to crumble away in neglect and to merely remain as an interesting monument of religious dogma.

div.head: French Deputy On Egyptian Nationalism.
div.p: Mr. Maurice Barrès, the Deputy and Academician, who has just returned from Egypt, has made the following statement to a repre sentative of the "Belair" respecting the Nationalist agitation in that country, a summary of which appeared in our special cable of the 17th.

"In the existing condition of affaire no Egyptian could seriously desire the disappear ance of European advisers. If England were to retire, and if she were not succeeded by France or some other European nation, the result would be return to anarchy. This would be felt as intolerable by the fellabs, who are bow acoustomed to justice and equity, which are, if you like, of a relative character, but still very appreciable, if only in the coll setion of taxes. There is, however, a very strong Nationalist sentiment in the hearts of the natives--that is to say their religious feel. ing and their attachment to Islam. Toleration is a natural gift of the Egyptian Mahomedians; but if they considered that offence bad been done to their religion, their feeling against the foreigner might become really active and even dangerous. Thus you see how Egyptian Nationalism is at the same time a very genuine feeling and one without any precise political object."

div.head: Egyptian State Railway Institute
div.p: The Egyptian State Railway Institute was en fete last Thursday evening, being the occasion of the annual ball. Many enjoyable fonctions are promoted by the entertainment committee during the year, but the annual bull is intended to and really does eclipse all. The arrangements were ou an elaborate scale and the comfort of the guests had received the fullest consideration. The approaches were enclosed in Arabic tentage while the balcony was transformed into a sitting out apartment and looked very comfortable decked with bunting and evergreen. The ball room itself was tastefully decorated, indeed better than we have yet seen it with flags and palms, while the chain like array of oriental lanterne lent additional charm to the pro ceedings. Some 200 persons accepted the committee's invitation amongst whom we noticed Macauley Bey and Mr. and Mrs Trevithick.

The string band of the King's Own Soottish Borderers played an excellent programme of music under the direction of Sergeant Grimrod which went a long way to make the funotion the nocess it really was.
Unfortunately the early morning hours brought wet weather which made the home going decidedly unpleasant over the disgrace. fal state of the surface of the Gbezireb Badran.
Messrs. Ison-Cooper and Whittle officiaiated as ball room stewards, and their arrangements were much appreciated.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN LAND ALLOTMENTS CO.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir, -The letter which you published yesterfor day, signed by four shareholders of the above Company, suggests a question which in these as difficult times, should be of very general ni interest The Company referred to is, I believe, y constituted under Egyptian Law and your be correspondenta state its object is the purchase ter and improvements of land in Egypt for resale; they further state that the Directors have cht invested in Cyprus sum not expected to on. exceed 2160,000. It appean to me that if the Di Company is an Egyptian one its sphere of action for limited responsibility is confined to Egypt alone, unless it is clearly stated in ita decree of incorporation, that its objects are of wider range than that stated in the letter above referred to. If I am right in this supposition no special resolution of general meetings, ordinary or extraordinary, can change this or subject to Egyptian law of limited responsibility, any transactions undertaken outside this country, and any agch business would be done on the personal responsibility of the directors. It is only right that this should be so, for otherwise any shareholder might find that his noney, which he had subscribed with the understanding that it should be invested in this country, more or less under his own supervision, was being spent in the middle of Ho the desert of Sabarah, or in some equally remote place, from which it might not be ensy to recall it. It is quite probable that some of your readers may be able to give some information on this subject. I only ask for it on general grounds, and not especially er with reference to the company above referred to.
I remain, yours truly,

div.head: The Government and the Crisis
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, – It is sincerely to be hoped that the Goveroment will not be induced to listen to the fallacious arguments of our local financiers, who imagine that a loan of two millions will materially relieve the present situation. The situation is clearing of itself, only this process must take time and it will be far clearer afterwards, if the Government does not try to bolster up a false position.
Truly yours,

div.head: The Egyptian Estates Limited. (Savoy Hotel Negotiations.)
div.p: The negotiations, which have been continuing of late between the Egyptian Estates Limited and the George Nangovich Hotels Company for the retrocession of the Savoy Hotel at Cairo are being actively pur sued and there is every hope that in a few days' time a satisfactory settlement will be be arrived at, which will free the Egyptian Estates from its embarrassing purchase. The final approbation will be given at an extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the George Nungovich Hotels Company, which will be convened at once after the agreement bas been arrived at. If it is decided to sanction the arrangement as to the retrocession of the hotel, no new hotel will be bailt by the company to take the I place of the Savoy Hotel as was originally intended after the hotel had been disposed of to the Egyptian Estates.

div.head: The City and Agricultural Lands of Egypt Limited.
div.p: The "Anglo Egyptian Mail" reports that a certain number of shareholders in the City and Agricultural Lands of Egypt, Limited, bave petitioned the Mixed Tribunals to decree the winding up of the company. They maintain that, notwithstanding the fact that the nominal headquarters of the concern are in London, it is merely an Egyptian joint stock company (société anonyme), which does not fulfil the conditions imposed by Egyptian law to ensure its validity. The Shareholders in I question, who bold some 1,000 shares ask that an official liquidator be appointed, and that the board be dissolved. It will be remembered that the company was formed scarcely a year ago, in order to purobase house property belonging to the Counts de Zogheb, and that the public issuo, which took place recently, was not a success.

div.head: Cairo Opera Season ("Carmen")
div.p: Mme Magne's "Carmen" was triumph o personality and interpellation : it proved how a really clever gifted artiste can transform herself at will into the most varied and conflict ing parts. In the first act she was the flaunting, bold, hande me factory girl bogdiling her brigadier for the sheer fun of so doing and by the mere contrast ber dovilry to the purity of the pale ooy Micaela. In the lon she was the gipsy, queen among ber sunggling tavern baunters, just decently grateful to the released prisoner, but far more excited by the bold toreror. Theo two acts were triomph. for ber every glance and movement The third at is I venture to believe, impossible for any bat Spaniards or a very, very fow Italians and Mme Magno is neither : and to me there seemed a touch of convention of adaptation, rather, of the part. But the last act again brought out her full powers. Her adoration for Escamillo, her annoyance with Don José and contempt for bis despair, her fright and rage at the danger, and then her death, those were consummate. Two particular features, the quick desperate quiver of her hands as sho retreated from him searching escape in vain, and her scream for Becamillo, heldur entranced, awe-struck, rather. It was a great performance needless to say, the music was AS child's play to her, not a shade of its cold, cynical subtelty escaped her, and she gave the fullest meaning to every intonation. Unusual especially was ber singing when with the chorus, never drowned by it, yet never overpowering it. It was remarkablo. M. Soubayran, was better than usual as Don José, especially at the end. Some of his higher notes were most telling.

M. Gorins was also gond, and deserved bis encore for the Toreador,' thongh be forced bis voice a little, it seemed, to obtain the effect. Mlle Talbert was admirably clear and correct M Micaela. The part suited ber and showed that she has an excellent sympathetic voice. The chorns were most adequate. Their acting, as well as their singing, was convincing and showed to better advantage, had their conductor realised more thoroughly the character of Bizet's music. It is a wonder that Carmen musio, torre fascinating every time one bears it, subtlo, unique, daring, absolutely decisive, the production of a real and unusual personality. M. Baron missed the clear, fire and sparkle of it, the crafty, 'diablerie' (the only word) the whole varied strength that distinguishes Bizet from all others. Yet it "went" all the same. The collective power of the singers achieved the result and Madame Magne crownedit.

div.head: Societe Des Concertes
div.p: The only two items in last Sunday's concert which one can mention with equanimity were the Schumann, which was just tolerable, and the ond of the Saint Saens 'deluge' when the violin soloist achieved a brilliant success all too short, slas, was his part, but it was instinct with the dignity and beauty of the music, admirable for tone resonance and absolute certainty. For the rest the orchestra were sheep without a sbepherd, burried headlong through the Bach into the Massenet, and thence into the beginning of the Saint Saëns, without breathing space until the violia solo bawan. Such aliwht continuity and interpretation as appeared was, all through, thanks to the leader of the violins. The conductor evidently was unable to deal with the programme. One would gladly have passed over the whole episode in silence but this attempt of the Society to start organised music in Cairo is so important, that one cannot allow their efforts to be wholly wasted, They have drawn up splendid programmes, and they have procured the services of an admirable orchestra. If the conductor cannot lead the orchestra or interpret the music, he should be left to such pieces and operas as are within bis scope. It w yuld be fatal to encourage throngh mere indul. gence a delusion, the results of which would discourage all music lovers from further attendance or efforts I hear that M. Massio, a famous violinist and musician, is in Cairo, and that he may be induced to conduct at the last four concerts. It is most earnestly to be hoped that he will consent so to do. Since writing this I hear, that M. Massie bas consented to conduct the next concert. It is just possible the date may have to be changed to Wednesday 29th : if that proves necessary, due notice will be given to all subscribers, as well as in the papers, as soon as possible.

We regret to announce the death of Mrs. Priend, wife of Mr. Astley, P. Priend, the Director of the Water Work Cairo, which ocurred at the Victoria Nursing Home on Wednesday afternoon, following an operation for appendicitis. Mrs. Friend had only beon ill for twelve day. The funeral cortege will leave the Victoria Nursing Home at 8.30 p.m. today. -

Rear Admiral Marous Lowther, who died last week at the age of 89, was serving in the "Hastings," stationed in the Mediterranean, wben difficulties arose between the Porte and Mebemet Ali, which resulted in 1840 in the British undertaking operations of the coast of Syria The "Hastings" was ordered to the scene of action, and on September 15 he took part in the capture of Batroon. He was next employed in the distribution of arms to the Maronites, and in October was present in the barge of the "Hastings" at the destruction of mine designed to blow up the eastern fort of Beirut. This brilliant exploit was carried out successfully under the direction of Commander Henry Worth, with the loss of one midshipman of the ship. For bis services during the campaign be received the Syrian medal, and in August, 1844, was promoted to lieutenant.

Mrs. Chatterton Adams was "at home" to her friends on Wednesday afternoon in her pretty new flat on the Pyramid Road, very many people taking advantage of their invite tions, and the gathering proving a thoroughly sociable one. The wide balconies were much patronized, the views across the fields of young crops to the distant hills on the Pyramid side and over the city to the guardian Citadel on the other, being particularly fine, even though threatening clouds bung low over the Mokat tams. Among the guests present were Col and Mrs. Duckett, Sir Reginald and Lady Oakes, the Misses Hyde Page, Mrs. Knight, Shakoor Bey with Mrs. Shakoor and their son and daughter, Mrs. and Miss de Bilinski, Miss Johnston, Mr. Melville, Miss Meade, Mr. Dickenson, Mr. and Mrs. Berry, Mr. G. div.head: Bulletin De La Bourse
div.p: Nous assistons décidément à une réaction, qu'avaient fait prévoir d'ailleurs la continuelle bausse des prix soľncidant avec la rareté des affaires. Le recul est-il da à des réalisations ou à une modification quelconque de la situation, voil ce qu'il est difficile de préciser. Cependant, les nouvelles du dehors continuent à être bonnes, le taux privé d'escompte diminue de 4 3 7/8% et les valeurs égyptiennes sont admirablement soutenues tant : Londres qu'à Paris. D'autre part, les récents acbats n'ont pas eu, croyons-nous, assez d'amplenr pour amener deja des réalisations. Il s'agit plutôt sans douto de positions qui venlent profiter de l'amélior tion sensible des prix pour liquider ou s'alléger, mais les acheteurs ayant dispara de la scène, les offres ont déterminé une réaction. C'est done l'invariable jeu de cache cache qui continue dans notre corbeille entre vendeurs et acheteurs.

Ainsi l'Obligation ancienne Crédit Foncier rétrograde de 304 à 295 francs. Le fléchisooment de la nouvelle est moins accentué de 259 1/2 à 258 1/2. En revanche, les Lots Tures progressent de 1 franc à 171 à cause de l'approche du tirage du ler Février.

Sur le bruit que le coupon serait inférieur celui de l'année posode, l'Agricole est délaissée à 7 11/16, contro 7 23/32 bier. Le pro position faite par un groupe financier d'étendre ses facultés de prêts attend l'approbation du Gouvernement

En ce qui concerne la National Bank, le prix avance de 91 1/16 . 21 9/16 en sympathie avec la hausse de Londres 21 5/8 et aussi en raison du manqne de vendeurs sur place. Il n'y a presque pas eu d'affaires.
Dans l'ensemble, du resto, les transactions ont été disséminées un peu sur toute la cote mais n'ont eu aucune importance. Aucune veleur n'a été l'objet d'une attention spéciale.

div.head: Socialism in Germany. Reichstag Isolated. Further Riots Anticipated.
div.p: Nine meetings of unemployed have been Bold bore, organised by the socialists. They were attended by over 12,000 men. A resolution was passed demanding immediate relief. The moorings were quiet The blood bed resulting from the meeting in front of the Reichstag was due to police taotice. The polioe laid about them mercilessly. Pools of blood were left on the pavement. The Reichstag and Imperial Palace are today isolated by dense oordons of police, armed pich revolvers, in anticipation of demonstrations in support of the socialist interpellation demanding the extension of Reichstag franchise to the Prussian Diet. Prince von Buelow, amid the protests of the socialiste, refused to discuss the matter as being outside the Reichatag's domain and warned the socialists that disorderly demonstrations would be vigorously reprobed. How they were responsible for yesterday's bloodshed. He unyod workers not to be misled. (Reuter)

div.head: The Norwegian Treaty
div.p: It is officially announced that in view of the Norwegian Treaty of 3rd November negotiations are proceeding between St. Petersburg and Stookholm on the one hand and Berlin and Stockholm on the other regarding the protection of Swedish interests by a special declaration, the maintenance of the status quo and the mutual recognition of a principle similar to that laid down in the Anglo Franco Spanish Mediterranean agreements of last year.

div.head: Mr. Birrell on Ireland
div.p: Mr. Birrell, speaking at Reading, said he was determined to maintain respect for the law in Ireland and to promote the necessary remedial legislation.

div.head: Tyne Shipbuilders Lockout.
div.p: In accordance with the look-out notices previously served by the employers, the shipbuilders on the Tyne and Wear will cease worth.

div.head: TIFLIS TREASURY VAN ROBBERY
div.p: A Russian, Kruschinsky, whilst attempting to chango notas belonging to the Tiflis Treasury Pan robbery, has been arrested here. (Router)

div.head: Collision of G.E.R. Steamer
div.p: The Great Eastern Railway Company's steamer "Amsterdam" has collided off the Hook of Holland in a fog with an unknown steamer. Her bows were torn away. The passengers escaped in boats.

div.head: Silver for America
div.p: The Treasury has purchased 200,000 ounces of silver at 56083. (Router)

div.head: Weather in Australia
div.p: Disastrous Heat Wave
Melbourne, January 22.

Over a hundred deaths from heat apoplexy have occurred. Disastrous bushfires have taken place in Victoria. Scores of settlers' homes have been burned and townships threatened Immense losses in live-stook have resulted. (Reuter)

div.head: THE MOROCCAN SITUATION.
div.p: TANGER, January 22.

Malay Hafid has been proclaimed at the holy city Wazzan, thus implying important religious support. Malay has preoccupied Settat from where the French withdrew as the town was beyond General D'Amade s sphere of occupation.

div.head: COMMERCIAL & LAND OF EGYPT. THE FINANCIAL CRISIS AFFECTED THE BUSINESS - A QUICK RETURN.
div.p: The second ordinary general meeting of the Commercial, Industrial and Land Company of Egypt, Limited, was held yesterday, at Salis. bury House, London-wall, EC, Mr. Scott Linge, J.P., occupying the chair.
The Secretary (Mr. Alfred Banbury) having read the notice convening the meeting, the report of the auditors was read by their representative, Mr. Shaw

The Chairman saids On rising to move the adoption of the report and balance sheet my first duty is to express my regret at the absence of Sir Richard Temple, the chairman of the company, who is away on the Continent and enable to get back in time to attend the meeting in those circumstances the directors beve done me the honour of asking me to preside at this general meeting of the company and to move the adoption of the report and balance sheet. I will turn at once to the accounts, as exhibited in the balance sheet. The accounts of the company and of the business conducted in Egypt have been audited by Messrs. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt, who are Chartered Accountants of London and Cairo, and they present this balance sheet, with the certificate attached thereto. I would rather in detail to the items of the account as follows. The authorised hospital of the company is £300,000 of that there was issued originally 157,701 ordinary shares and 5,000 deferred shares; but it will be within the knowledge of gentlemen who have followed events in Egypt that very shortly after the formation of this company . period of financial crisis and industrial depression commenced in that country, which was not without disastrous results to this company; and one of the consequences of that state of affairs was that the directors in the interests of the company, owing to the non-payment of the calls which had been made from time to time on the shares, were compelled to forfeit a very large number of the primeval allotments, the figures in question being 58,724 ordinary shares, representing £58,724 of capital. Io respect of those shares, however, there have been certain payments made, and to the extent of some monto the company reaped the benefit, and you will obaryo that there is an item of hodount of $10,889 18., representing the count the company received in respect of those shares which were afterwards forfeited.

There appears on the statement of capital account the regrettable fact that £8,808 18. is in arrear now in respect of calle des apor shares issued. No steps have, so far, boon. taken in connection with those shares : but it is obvious that unless within a very reasonable time the holders of those share fulfil their obligations to the company, it will be the day 1 of the directors to forfeit thou shares also. and the parties who have paid curtain goms in respect of them will thereby love their interest in the company. The reason why there has been difference made between cortaid 10 tions of the shareholders is that looks who still remain on the books of the company in respect, of shares not paid ap have paid larger pro: portion of their indebtedness to the company than those whose shares have already been for, feited. The result of the notion taken by your board is that the amount of l ed capital at the present time is £95,173 76., that being, made up by shared which are made at fully. paid and in respect of the date offered for subscription and subscribed for in cash, Then the sundry creditors, a set out in the balance sheet, amount to £86,876 76 ; that item is a very heavy one, and reference to it will have to be made in the subsequent remarks that it will be my duty to submit to you. The balance carried to the credit of profit and loss amounts to £7,710 28 On the assets side of the balance sheet stock in hand, work in progress, and work completed but not delivered amounts to £76,599 9s. 3d. Sundry debtors and bills receivable, less reserve for bad debts, stand at £71,078 12s. 4d. In arriving at that figure care has been taken, I am informed by the auditors, to investigate the stability of the varibus accounts, and in arriving at this ulti mate net figure they have taken the precaution to set wide what, in their opinion, in Mufficient reserve fund to allow for any bad debts which may recrue. Accounts paid in advance amount to £2,269, and that item called for no remark. Buildings, plants, and machinery, less depreciation, amount to £5,630 198. 2d. office furniture and fittings, London and Egypt, le-s depreciation, £984 169, 10d., freehold land at Sapti-h, in Cairo, after provision for a contingent interest therein--bis Land being mortgaged to the extent of £1,016 16.- amounts to £9,475. Then there is good Will of the business of R. Kuster and Co., £4,585 152. 5d. ; sondry payments in conneotion with preliminary expenses-payment ponant to contract for parohsee of rights from vendors, £15,000, and amount paid ander contracts dated April 30, 1906, namely, £14,001, brokerage, commission, law charges, and stamp duty on transfer--these items make, together, £30, 198109 d. Then we have stamps our bearer warrant not yet delivered, £279 180 6d., and each at the bank and on hand in London and Egypt, £152 16s. 6d

I should remark, perhaps-aud this is to some extent & personal explanation---that subsequent to the formation of the company, and after it had gone to allotment, I was invited by your directors to join the board, under the articles of association, as an additional director, and, if I may say so, I think one of the reasons which induced your directors to take that step was that I was introduced to them as a commercial man having knowledge of commercial affairs, and in that respect likely to be of some assistance to them in the conduct of the affairs of the company. In that connection it became my duty to investigate as far as possible the conditions and circumstances under which you were working, and I found, in effect, that only two options of those recited in the original prospectus were dealt with by your directors; the others were rejected for various reasons. It was within the discretion of the directors to determine which options they should exercise, and it was their bounden duty | to investigate, so far as lay in their power, the value of the options to the company, if exercised, and also to take into consideration the financial condition of the company, and having regard to the critical condition which existed at that time iu Egypt, I am bound to say that |I think the directors exercised a very wise discretion in not entering into any further options than those to whom they were already committed, because a somewhat abnormal state of affairs had arisen, apart from the conditions in Egypt, owing to the fact that a saisio bad been placed on the funds of the company in Egypt in connection with a misunderstanding -we will call it--between the company and certain parties who had give the options in alluded in the original prospectus. This was a difficult matter to bendle; but your board was able, by taking an energetic and somewhat costly step, to relieve the company of the saisie placed on the funds and liberate the weepy then lying in Egypt. They then directed their attention primarily to the development and organisation of the industrial business which they had acquired that being the business of R. Kustor and Co., well-known, well-cota blished, and favourable undertaking carrying on business in connection with iron work very largely, supplying girders and similar articles to contractors, and also minor articles which could be classed under the head of ironmongery. Mr. Walker Ablitt was the proprietor of the business in question, and, in the terms of the contract for sale, was appointed manager of the business of Kaster and Co. in Egypt for a period of five years. Mr. Ablitt had a solo charge of that business prior to the formation of the company, and he took payment for the Assets of the undertaking, in accordance with the contract for sale, in shares of the company. In that connection he naturally became an important shareholder of the company, and in his fiduciary position as manager of the basis ness in Egypt undertook a highly responsible position.

Mr. …. has from time to time been in conference with the board, and on one or two occasions directors have paid visits to Egypt for the purpose of dealing with the affairs of the compe pop cooling with Mr. Ablitt The desire on their part has been to work for a possible in entire harmony with Mr. Ablits, and tort o in a form that is looking after his interest w large horobolder in the company, who was also looking after the interdite of the company corporate body. We found a very natural attitude of mind, shall lay on the part of Me Ablitt ray that, daving on the proprietor of the business for den offen, having laid the sole my in its condot and in all item moth be the moth imbued with the feeling that is will be business and that he is entitled to d o it in sticla manter as he shoughs belonging to bio owa lighte. I think Shareholder mere body l recognise that it is absolutely cool for the well-being of any undertaking that the management and the bo and should be working in harmony, and that shere should not be sentriotion to them, if she best rouler and to be obtained from an enterprise of this description: The views of Mr. Ablitt and thors of the board lave diverged to domettent on ostain in connection with the conduct of the boy and the report of the auditor to the company director the attention of the board to certain foto in connection with oba management and conduct of the busincu in Ropi Purtametely Mr Ablitt is in Bugland at the present time, he is also present in this room, and I have no doubt that be will be perfectly willing to recognise any fair and proper suggestione coming from the board, and also the bin duty to the board to obey all their proper unreasonable requests, and it in obviously the duty of the direction, Mis-& vis their position with the baseboldos to take quick steps, they know to be in the true and proper interests of the company. I do aut propure to carry that point any further, but bareIy to point out to the shareholders that the board is determined that everything possible that ona be done shall be done to make the bad issues in Egypt a spoonful and a paying one, and we look to Me Ablitt to do carry out the Arrangements sod Abe wonders of the board that the company, at any este, shall be worked in a Inapper within ita mends, and not driven into a position of financial danger by ill-considered and not thoroughly thought out action on the part of the management.

Now, the other option which was exercised by the board yw in respect of freehold land in Cairo, which did not belong to Kester's business, but we mociated with it to the extent that it belonged to certain people in trust, and the buildings, or the main business of Kaster and Co, carried out on the land in question. By the toto of the option at a fortunate time the company was able to achieve a very popsidetablo pruft on reale, and practically the profit which is carried to the credit of profit and los account crgo from the heroise of that option, because you will observe io timing to the polite and loss count, that the amount of profit origin from the business of Messrs. R. Kuster and Co. for the your under review ww $694 only. The profit accruing 09 the exercise of the option of the rengle of land at Boulao was £14,915 80. Td. I should men Lion, in this connection, that the resale which took place wasabjeet to the terms of a contract ropited this the purchase consideration was to be paid in inglegents, and up to the present time in toopoot of the total puroboro, price, the com of £45,000 has been received, there remain ing is round figor $60,000 still to be paid. Thadi however, is not all to be paid to us because the land in question was subject to a very considerable mortgage It was taken over by the purchaser, and obey undertook to redeem the mortgage in the terms of the contract for sale. Therefore, although the profit has been earned upon the sale of the land, it has not yet been received into the coffers of the company, and the deal cannot be considered complete until the whole of the probase confidential is paid. The property has not been transferred to the purchasers, and remains poder the control of the company. We are therefore in this position : that we have sold the land at an agreed price, and, in respect of the purchase price, we have received £25,000, 80 that our position in this connection is secure. But, as I said before, we cannot definitely determine that we have received this profit dotil the whole of the purchase price has been paid, and having regard to these circumstances, having regard to the position pé effein in Egypt and to the amount of money involved in Kaster's business it was deemed wise on the part of the directorate not to distribute any of the profits, but to carry them forward to the credit of parotid and lows account, and with that action live true to think any reasonable and conservative member of the company will agreo, I should mention that the auditors' report calls attention to the amount of $6,49 1s, 7d. As 'principally representing the balance of pools looted debts of Meers R: Kuster and Co wat Jono 30, 1906. We understand that these debts are guaranteed by your mooger in Egypt."

The explanation of that clause in the auditor's report is very simple, and I can briefly stato it as follows: At the time the puroba a made from Mr. Ablitt, of Messrs. Kuster and Co, be pustrentwort that the book debts appearing on the balance sheet then prepared should be collected on behalf of the company. And at the end of 1007 we found that this Amount of the old book debts had not been collected or approximately. There was some other item' in the accounts; but, broadly speaking it represents that fact, and therefore we had arrived it in range with Mr. Ablitt whereby we could endeavour to settle up the back reckoning as on June 30, 1907. Mr. Ablitt, in respect of his purchase consideration, bad bostado comodo number of fully-paid share in the company and the question is ideal with this amount while bit Bed guaranteed. In the guarantee itself in the contract for male there was no specific time within which Mr Ablitt was to pay up their uncollected old dabu, said there was scheme suggested whereunder to settle the old outstanding account forfeiture of certain of the shares which had been issued to Mr. Ablitt should be made ; but we are not satisfied that that is quite in accordance with the law, and in the meantime, at any rate," that matter must and over for further consideration. They are undoubtedly good debts to the company, Loomuse we buvo Mr. Ablitt's guarantee, and in report of that guarantee we are totaled • certain number of stringed shares which they would otherwise be entitled to, and those sharo stand to the company, 14.security for the amount of ibo outstanding accounts. Now, that is briefly the position of the company, and the futgro of the undertaking will depend, entirely upon the successful, overgetic, and Careful. Ornament throb in Egypt. We cannot expect a repetition of the fortunate circumstance of the wise of an option on Land and the role of it, and we shall have to be dependent for the proventy i at any itate -upon the income earned by the business of Kuster and Co., for the provision of return upon the capital of the company Therefore that point is one of great anxiety to the board, and one which must be dealt with in careful and proper manner if we are going to see any satisfactory return apon, the Amount of capital invested in this company. According to the terms of the articles of association, the board of the company are entitled to do opt directors within a certain period, and the tenure of office of any director no oo opted is to bo till the next general meeting. It therefore becomes my duty as a co-opted member of the board to submit myself for re-election to the shareholders of the company, and it lies in their hands to determine whether or not in their opinion it is desirable, in the interests of the company, that I should continue as a member of the board. All I can say is that, having familiarised myself with the nature of the undertaking, and with the character of the business which has been acquired, I have little hesitation in saying that it has elements within it of very considerable value, which, if properly handled, will result in a steady, although not an exaggerated, retour upon the capital of the company which has been invested, and so long as I have the confidence of the shareholders, and remain a director of the company, I shall do all that lies in my power towards that end. I have now pleasure in moving the adoption of the report and balance sheet which have been presented to you. (Applause.)
Colonel A. M. Harington Bey seconded the motion.

Mr. Monikland said that he observed on the balance sheet that the issued capital consisted of 157,701 ordinary shares. He wished to ask how many of the shares were subscribed for by the public, and how many were issued to the vendors or others ! -

This "W & very lange son to have spent in management in the course of fifteen months and he thought the shareholders were entitled to have some particulars of that item.

As regards the £1,193 10s. 8d, which is an increase of the second £14,000, it was paid in respect of brokerage, comm e charges, And. wamp duties on telers, which were not included in the control rooted in the prosper

And go. perally all the preliminary expenses whatsoever." Who knew nothing about stamp duties and transfer, but one was led to believe that they were going to pay everything out of that £28,000.

The Chairman: As a matter of fact those items were adjudged, at the time the matter was settled, not to be included in the contract. I have not gone into this question personally, because it was an accomplished fact at the time I joined the board, and I assume that the directors of the company were properly cad legally advised as to their obligations in regard to the comet, and this was the decision they arrived at after ouob advice.
Mr. Monkland and that he was blaming anybody; all he was taking for w for information.

Mr. Monkland remarked that he supposed that was all the money which the company bad in the world, excepting what they might expect to get from trading

The Chairman said that he had already explained that there were considerable amounts still due from an important company in connection with the purchase of the land. Of course, be quite agreed that if they continued to apuud £8,000 overy from west ham, and only cried 4500, they would soon be in bankruptcy. He did not know, however, whether: Ma Monkland had been a shareholder since the inception of the company; but if not, it would be of value to tell him that the 100st abnormal state of things arose in this company which required the expenditure of an enormous amount in order to set things right. le the earlier stages of the company the directors were face to face with lawsuit in Egypt which threatened immediate disaster, and it was found secondary to taking steps to remove that condition of things, which was a costly matter to the company. of that expenditure of £8,000 be thought they might safely say that £5,000 of it was abugrinal expenditure, and would probably never recur. Ho then gave particulars of the various items included in the £8,004, and pointed out that the expenses incidental to the removal of the ssisie in Egypt snouted to £3,059 aod the payments to managing directors to £1,615. Mr. Monkland observed that, having regard to the whole of the circumstances of the company and its trading, the stook, Amounting to £76,00, was exceedingly high." He thought the shareholders would like to hear some explanation as to that item.

The Chairman : In answering that question I shall have to make reference to one of those matters which is in dispute between the board of directors in London and the management in Egypt. The board is of opinion that that amount of stock is too heavy, having regard to the turnover of the undertaking, and it has been a matter of debate between the board the manager in Egypt as to what steps shall be taken to reduce that stock, and also what is a proper and reasonable stock to carry, having regard to the character of the business carried on in Egypt. We hope that before Mr. Ablitt leave for Egypt we shall have arrived at a satisfactory understanding with with him in respect to that item, and also that we will have arranged with him to take such steps as will relieve the finances of the company by reducing that item which, in the opinion of the board, is far too heavy. We have equipped the business of R. Kuster and Co, with a very substantial amount of capital very during the year under review, in addition to its previous resources : but we must eat our control according to our doch, sad that not vill have to be impressed upon the minds of the management in Egypt, and, whey, I have hopes that we shall arrive at entidade tory understanding, so that vt the coming of the next meeting of the shareholders may present balance sheet showing different condition of affairs.

Mr Monkland handed in a demand for a poll, which the Chairman directed should be taken on February 13 next.

Colonel Harington second the resolution, which was also carried on a show of handss

div.head: Money and Share Market
div.p: The reduction of the Bank of England rate to 5 per cent yesterday was anticipated as a matter of course in financial circles, and it is even suggested that we shall shortly be back to the old rate of 47 per cent. All the conditions are favourable to low rate. The Bank is getting into a very strong position, and money cortines to flow in freely. The return this week shows an addition of a further 1 million to the reserve, and a 5 per cent. rate in present conditions is likely to prove more than sufficieutly effective. The persistent forcing down of discount rates is, however used as an Argoment against a lower rate Since the ship ments of gold to America ceased, and the prospect of e-ier conditione became brighter, rates have dwindled until three months' paper bow realises no more than 47% of even less than this figure, and the probabilities are that it will go still lower.

Money is abundant, and overnight accomodation is easily obtainable at 817 per cent and at four sper cent for week. After the announcement of the reduction in the Bank rate elearing banks reduced their deposit rate to 81 per cent.

The Bank return takes an excellent sbowing. Although over £600,000 in gold was exporter, the stock of coin and ballion is op £1,020,000. The active note circulation contracted to the ex. tent of £574,0 0, so that the reserve is higher by £1,594,000, making a total of £25,847,000. This compares with total of £22,593,000 in the corresponding weeks last year when the Bank rate was also lowered to 5 per cent. The proportion to liabilities is 521%as agaisnt 453 %year ago
The quotation for bar gold is lower on the week at 778 9d.

The silver market bas shown considerable fluctuations. The quotation, after being down to 25 d., improved to 26 tod., on betier news from Indis, but later fell away again to 28, H. Yesterday is left off at 25 7/8.

Consistency is not one of the chief virtues of the Stoek Exchange, and the pure of events bring some curious instances of its erratie tendencies. One would have imagined that the advent of cheaper money and a reduction in the Bank mate to 5 per cent would have affect ed prices lavourably, but the very opposite has been the result, prices falling away in all directions after the bouncement of the directors decision yesterday. Of course, the secret of the matter this: in these times there is such a paucity of genuine iovestinest! business that the speen lative ele went utilise every opportunity to put up prices in actieipa ! tion of realising at a profit immediately things promise to go better. The reduction in the Bank rate had been gonerally expected, bence for a few days previous to the usual meeting of the Court, the market had displayed & fim tone on professional buying. The speculative Dator of the business transacted was apparent, And the extent of it was realised yesterday After the Bank decision, profit-taking being the order of the day.

The weakness of the mining market on the Announcetent that the Premier Company's dividend had been postponel owing to the great falling off in the demand for diamonds as the result of the American crisis, has not helped matters in other departments.
Government stocks have been generally steady. Indian issues were weak at one time, but have since been firmer, but quiet. Consols on the week are rather higher at 83 15/16.
There has not been much doing in international bonds, but the tone has been for the most part firm. Russians have received support, and the Fives have risen to 91 1/4, the Fours closing at 814

There was some selling of Japanese from Paris on Monday, but they recovered the following day, and for the greater part of the week have been inactive, although the second series of Pives advanced yesterday to 97%.
To-day Japanese bave given way from 1/4 to 5/8.

There has again been a good deal of irre is gularity in the movements of home railway kabares. The market was very firm at the Hi-opening, but the advance was not maintained, ok except in a few cases. We pointed out last od week that there bas recently been subatan r tial amount of speculation in this section, and 1 yesterday, after the Bapk rate was reduced, in there was a rusb to sell, and prices follaway an all-round. South Eastern "A led with a decline of 1 to 359, Great Easteru dropped in to 74, North Western 1 to 1474, and Caledonian Def and North British Def. 4 to 28 and 86 me respectively,
To-day home rails have been offered, Brighton er "A" have lost 2 1/2, Metropolitan 1, and North as British Ord. 3/4 Midland Def, are firm at a at rise of 3/4.

Two or three events have helped to keep the American market rather weak. First of all it was announced that the Secretary to the Treasury had resigned, and as is usual in the case of such rumours, an attempt was tondo to supply a reason for the step alleged to have been taken.One of these was that Mr. Cortelyou and Mr. Roosevelt had quarrelled over the be former's currency proposals. The report of the resignation was contradicted, and shortly atterwards there was another report regarding further action against the trusta Shares have not received much support, and the movements have tot been very important. Yesterday the opening was steady, but there was a reaction after the receipt of selling orders from Wall Street.
To-day movements have been downwards Grand Tuuk 2nd Pf. have shed 4 to 1015, Aud B the 1sc PC to 111. Cauadian Pac. are 3 A lower at 152 3.4.

The Egyptian market has been rather remarkable one this week, for the reason that with about two exceptions, the movements have been absolutely featureless The exceptions UE have been in the case of National Banks and Abonkir, both of which have further progress, ou guod support from Egypt, and also from this side. Nationals have been put up to 2 and seem firm at the price. We mentioned in a recent article that an increased coupon night be expected next time, and probably the present strength of these shares is to an extent attributable to this anticipation, although, o course, the excellent position the Bank now boids is generally recognised, and it was in the natural Order of things that the share would show – considerable appreciation de when once the selling incidental to the crisis in Egypt ceed. Indeed, we forecasted this at the time.
Aboukir close at 14-11/16 after having been as good as 1 23,32-1.

There has been a slight demand for United Egyptian Lanus on rumours that the company has arranged an isle of 5 per cent, bonds with Pou its creditors. We understand that a reconstruccio tion of the Board is by no means unlikely the Estates remain a weak market at about 68. 9d. Until something definite is known as to the out stops being taken by the company to meet their Various ou moituents in Egypt, it is unlikely Estates remain a weak market at about 68. 9d. Until something definite is known as to the steps being taken by the company to meet their various commitments in Egypt, it is unlikely we shall see any pronounced tendency in these shares.

Union Foncière has been in quiet demand at about 4 ). These shares present a very attractive yield to investors at this price, and it would seem that in view of several good land sales during the past year, the company should be able to increase its last dividend of 4 per cent. Khedivial Mail has been rather neglected, though at 19/6 there seems to be support. Alexandria Water experienced a sharp set back to 104 sellers, although there is no apparent reason for the fall dairy remain firm 18,7 16-4 on the improvement in price of Credit Fonciére in Paris to 716, this latter being probably due to anticipation of an increased coupon. Egyptian Markets and Salt and Soda are flat at 24/. 14/16 spectively.
New Egyptian have been asked for at 9a. 6d., but there appear to be few sellers about at this figure. Corporation of Western Egypt remain about 3/8-1/2.

The issue of £1,000,000 of new capital by the Randfonteit Estates was not very favourably received by dealers in the expression their feelings in regard to the matter. The issue noged kaffinand Rbodo lend who ground in the early part of the wout, but some buying or Modders from Paris gave support to the market which began to pick op. The optimistic foeling was however tot long maintained, owing to a rumour whibb began to circulate fist payment of the divi dend of 10/ declared on the 17th December last on Premier Deferred, was to be postponed, and later the rumour was confirmed by calle This news coming on top of the issue by Randfontein Estates, caused the mdrliet to be very weak, and also exercised a depressing effect on other sections.
Yesterday Premier Diamond fluctuated to a considerable degree, but at the close they were higher at 614.
South African bave further declined to-day. Premier Det. have lost it to 5 H.

div.head: Agonies of Sciatica

p.hi: One of Liverpool's Best-Known Men describes how his torture was (by Dr. Williams' Pink pills)

div.p: Mr. William Longridge is a retired police sergeant who now holds a position of trust in one of the principal banks in Liverpool. He is 55 years of age and was for many years connected with the Liverpool Police Force, from which service he has been pensioned off He received special awards for the Liverpool Shipwreck and Humane Sople ty, and is a man highly respected throughout the city. Recently he was attacked by Sciation in such an acuto form that he was onge confined to bed for five weeks and three days. He was completely cured by Dr. Williams Pink Pills, and he says: -"I have not felt any trace of Sciatica since." A SIMPLE CAUSE " What was the cause of your complaint "he was asked by a reporter who called upon him at his house, 354, Scotland-road, Liverpool. "Simply through getting my feet wet." he replied "I first felt a shivering feeling coming over me, and this turned to slight symptoms of Rheumatism. Then I began to feel as if I was paralysed in the lower extremities, and was unable to move without pains like bot needles running down my thighs and legs; these pains of Sciatica nearly drove me mad. When I attempted to walk I became so faint that I had to turn back home. My left leg became almost useless, and at times swift prins shot right down to my feet. For hours I would roll and toss in bed through sheer torture, and bende of perspiration rolled off my forebrand, Doctors prescribed all sorts of medicines, but I seemed to get worse. I then underwent a course of massage, but the Sciatica pains increased in fury. "My sister came to visit me and insisted that I should try Dr. Williams' Pink Pills. My wife purchased some, and I took the doses regularly. I derived. little benefit and so continued the medicine. THE ONLY EFFECTIVE MEDICINE. "Soon I wade Auch improvement that I felt sure Dr. Williams' Pink Pills were the only medicine to put me on my feet. In a few weeks I was able to get up. I could eat and digest my food, and then began to exercise without feeling any afterwards. tress. My cure took place some months ago and since then I have not felt any trace of Sciatica's pains. "I was cured by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale people, and I feel it my duty to make known the wonderful curative power of this medicine. I found that Dr. Williams Pink Pills restored my nervous system and Nourished and enriched my blood Victims of Societies nood their veins filled with the Now, Pure, Rich Blood applied by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People, which have cured many of Sciatica Rheumatism, Paralysis, St. Vitus's Dance, Gout, Neuralgia and Headaches. Only the genu. 11 ine pills cure and substitutes should be refused because they are worse than useless. The pills that have cured are Dr. Willisins, Pink Pills for Pale People (seven Words Sold by all obgmists and draggiats at P.T. 18 the box and P.T. 70 tor six boxes.)

div.head: Municipalite D'Alexandrie
div.p: AVIS

Le Samedi 25 Janvier 1908 de 10 heures du matin à midi, la Municipalité procèdera à la vente aux enchères publiques près de la Porte Rosette d'une quantité de pierres (Kantaris, Moellons, Dakehoums) provenant de la démolition des Fortifications Sud.
Ces pierres sont divisées en lots de 20 à 100 m3.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'en chère de 1 % et déposer le 10% de la valeur de la marchandise achetée au moment de la vente et effectuer le paiement intégral la Caine Municipale, le lendemain du jour de l'adjudication.

Ils auront à supporter les droits de carrière au profit de la Ville et devront enlever les pierres achetées dans un délai de dix jours sous peine de folle enobère pour compte de l'adjudicataire et de perte du dépôt de 10%.
L'Administrateur, (
Sign) W. P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie le 18 Janvier 1908. 31795-3-3

div.head: DELEGATION MUNICIPALE.
div.p: La Délégation Monicipale n'est réunie le 21 Janvier 1908 à 4 heures et 1/2 p.m. sous la présidence de S. E le Dr. Schiess Pacha Etaient présents MM. Yehis Pache Abany Bey, Escoffier, Ralli, Dr. G. Valensin, membree.
W. P. Chataway, administrateur
1. Sedky, secrétaire général.

Elle prend connaissance d'une note du service vétérinaire informant que le modèle de Toiture adopté par une Commission spéciale pour le transport des viandes de l'abattoir a donde los monltats les plus satisfaisants et qu'il serait nécessite dans un bat d'hy. giène de généraliser ce système de transport.
La Délégation adoptant cette mani re de voir déolde d'inviter les bouchers à se munir de voitures da même modale pour le transport des viandes et leur donne à cet effet un délai de trois mois.
La Délégation pris connaissado do di verses mesures adoptées par les services pour les poursuites exercer en cas de falsification da lait tant contre les indigènes que contre les étrangers.
Elle charge les services sanitaires d'élaborer dans un but analogue une régiementation contre la falsification de beurre.

La Délégation pour des raisons de salubrité publique et de convenance regrette de pe pouvoir faire droit à une demande de M. Ibrahim Deff, tendant & transporter et déposer les im: mondioen de la Ville sur ses terrains de Mariout près de la Mollabs.

Divers maçons ayant présenté une plainte à la Municipalité au sujet des rigueurs du règlement sur les constructions particulière. ment pour ce qui concerne les légères modifi. cations et pour les constructions de peu d'importance, la Delegation décide de renvoyer ootte plainte à l'étude du Comité des travaux publics. .
La Délégation adjuge à M. Th. Autofage, plus bas offrant, la fourniture des articles ne Cesaires aux rouleaux compresseurs.
Elle renvoie aux services pour rapport les offres présentées pour la fourniture de gar goailles et de ciment.

La Délégation émet un avis favorable aux exodents et omprises évalués par le Conseil d'estimation dans sa sanoe du 29 novembre 1907 et décide de les soumettre à l'approba tion de la Commission Municipale.

Statuant sur une demande de M. Comas pour l'établissement d'un bain de mer à Anfouchy, la Délégation serait disposée a lui accordoe patte autorisation, mais elle de mande an pelable connaitre la rede VADOS que intéressé aura à payer de ce chef la Municipalité ainsi que le tarit des bains.
M. Comas devra se conformer au cabier des charge
Sur le proposition de l'Inspecteur Sanitaire, la Délégation autorise les dépenses né. Baires pour apporter certaines améliorations moitaires aux mosquées Banhoury et Ham doulah

A cette occasion elle d'cido d'attirer l'at tention de l'Administration Générale des Wakfa sur l'utilité qu'il y aurait à prendre les mecore voulues pour remédier au drainage des mosquées dont la canalisation serait défeetuose et d'inviter les mé lecins sanitaires al vérifier si toutes les conditions hygiéniques des diversas moegubos sont observées.

La Délégation prend connaissanoo, d'une réclaination adressée par les divers carriers de La Ville au sujet d'une imposition que le Gouvernement leur fait payer en plus de la rede vance qu'ils paient à cet effet à la Municipalité et décide de communiquer cette plainte au Ministèro.

La Délégation prend connaissance d'une domande de la Société Générale d'électricité pour l'adaptation aux voitures de louage de taximètres à l'instar de certaines villes d'Europe. Elle décide de transmettre cette de mande à la Police en l'informant qu'elle ne verrait pas d'objection à cette innovation pourvu qu'ello D'ait qu'un caractère facultatif et que le droit au tarif promulgué par la Mu. nicipalité soit toujours conservé au Public.
La Délégation prend note des comptes préliminaires de l'exercice 1907 et décide de les soumettre à la séance de la Commission Modicipale qui aura lieu mercredi 29 Janvier 1908.
La séance est levée à 7 heures p.m.

div.head: TO OUR VISITORS
div.p: The Egyptian Gazette has much pleasure in presenting to its subscribers the accompanying description of some of the many interesting routes by which they may travel homewards. Great care has been taken to arrange them as accurately and concisely as possible, and it will be found that none of them are fraught with difficulty. In choosing the route home there are several things to be considered. To begin with there is the difference in climate between Egypt and the various points at which you may arrive in Europe.

This depends partly upon the month in which you leave Egypt, for Cairo in January may be a little warmer than the Riviera and possibly not so warm as Sicily, but in March it will be warmer than Rome, and more uniformly warm than many other places in Europe.
Many people leave Egypt far too early in the year, for as a rule the weather in April and May is perfect. The warmest place to go to on leaving Egypt is Sicily.

Some will want to take into consideration the number of days to be spent at sea, and we therefore subjoin a list shewing the time occupied on each of the various routes between Egypt and the Continent of Europe.
They are as follows:-
The long sea routes—from Port Said or Alexandria to Plymouth, Southhampton, London or Liverpool—occupy about 14 days. The short ones are as follows:—

The steamers of the P.&O., the Egyptian Mail S.S,. Co., North German Lloyd, Orient, and Messageries Maritimes are the largest. The Anchor, British India, Bibby and Henderson Lines are also excellent, and their steamers are largely patronised by travellers to Egypt.
As regards the train journeys from Cairo, the shortest is that to Alexandria, without change (3 hours). That to Port Said can now be made without change in 4 ½ hours.

The least expensive way to England is by the Moss, Papayanni, Prince, and Westcott lines of steamers from Alexandria to Liverpool. The German Levant line has also good steamers from Alexandria to Hamburg.

The quickest through Continental routes are by P.&O. Brindisi express from Port Said, by the Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., from Alexandria to Marseilles and the Austrian Lloyd Trieste Vienna express from Alexandria.

As regards heavy luggage, it must be borne in mind that very little luggage is allowed free on the railways of Europe, but there are several good and responsible forwarding agents in Egypt who undertake at a fixed charge to deliver packages to any address in Europe. The Egyptian Mail S.S. Co., have also made arrangements whereby luggage can be collected and sent to any address.

The quickest manner of getting to Europe from Port Said is undoubtedly by the fast Mail Steamers "Osiris" and "Isis" to Brindisi. One of these leaves Port Said every week, as soon as possible after receiving the Indian mails from the great liner arrived from Bombay.

These small but comfortable ships have enormously powerful engines, and attain a very high rate of speed. They are called the "Ferry Boats" having been specially built to carry the British mail from Port Said to Brindisi. If you are going straight through to England you will find the train waiting at Brindisi which will take you to Calais without changing. It has complete arrangements for sleeping and eating on board, and you should arrive in London on the fifth day from leaving Port Said.

div.head: SICILY.
div.p: The direct route to Sicily is by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers which leave Alexandria weekly for MESSINA, where one takes train to TAORMENA, one of the most charming and popular places on the island. Giardini is the station at which to alight, and the drive up to Taormina is most delightful, occupying about one hour. In and around the town is much to interest the visitor. The theatre is of Greek origin, but restored under the Romans. CATANIA is the starting place for the ascent of Etna, and here also is a fine Cathedral. The Greek, Roman, and Saracenic remains that are found all over the island, are an endless sources of pleasure. SYRACUSE has an interesting history, having been a Greek city, which was designed by Demosthenes in B.C. 413, and taken by the Romans in B.C. 212, when Archimedes was slain—his tomb is to be seen. The cathedral was once an ancient pagan temple. PALERMO, with about 300,000 inhabitants, is the capital of the Island, and enjoys a delightful climate. Much of interest is to be found in this fine city. The Palazzo Reale is of Saracenic origin and close to it the church of S. Giovannia degli Eremiti with its picturesque cloisters. The Cathedral, Museum, Botanic Gardens, Villa Giulia and Royal Park are also worth a visit.

div.head: CENTRAL ITALY.
div.p: The fine steamers of the North German Lloyd leave Alexandria every Wednesday during the season for Naples, the voyage being only 3 days.

NAPLES is also reached in 10 hours from Palermo by the Florio-Rubattino Co.'s steamers, which leave daily. One cannot approach Naples or leave it without wishing to explore some of its islands, besides the lovely places on its bay—Castellamare and Sorrento. The small steamer that takes you to Sorrento [you can drive too] will take you on to Capri.

From Naples to ROME is a train journey of but five hours. All who can will devote at least one week to visiting the many historical and interesting portions of the Eternal City, whose charms and beauties are too well-known to need comment here.

Leaving the Eternal City with much regret, a railway journey of five hours brings you to FLORENCE, where another week can well be spent admiring the City of Flowers and its surrounding country. In Florence itself the churches and galleries are of absorbing interest, whilst the local promenades and excursions should not be omitted. The Cascine is the most attractive and fashionable promenade in Florence, whilst the Viale dei Colli, one of the finest walks in Europe, opened 35 years ago, goes winding up through the hills a distance of four miles. The most delightful excursion outside Florence is that to Vallombrosa, with its Monastery 3,300 feet above the sea level. This is made first by ordinary train from Florence to St. Ellero, thence by cog-wheel railway to Saltino. The ascent through groves of oaks takes an hour, and most striking panoramas are unfolded to view.

PISA is easily reached from Florence in about 2 hours ; here there is a fine Cathedral and the Leaning Tower. A stay of at least one night should if possible be made in order to enjoy the view from the Campanile at sunset.

VIAREGGIO. One of the most delightful places on the Italian Riviera near Pisa and on the main line from Rome to Genoa. It is a very convenient half-way house between Egypt and England, and where living is reasonable and the air and surroundings exceptionally good.

div.head: NORTHERN ITALY
div.p: GENOA (La Superba).—The most picturesque and interesting city in Italy, with the record of having one of the lowest death averages of European cities and a phenomenally equable temperature—warm in winter and deliciously cool breezes from the surrounding mountains and the Mediterranean in summer.

The patriarchal home of Italy's most ancient nobility, whose palaces, gardens, and famous collections of statuary, frescoes, and paintings, are a constant delight to thousands of travellers who annually sojourn in Genoa. Then there are the superbly decorated medieval churches containing exquisite marble columns and historical paintings, and the incomparable Campo Santo filled with its wonderful tombs.
From Genoa to Milan is a matter of only three hours by rail.

MILAN is a good centre for Northern Italy before making the tour of the Lakes. The Cathedral is the principal attraction, with its beautiful windows illustrating the History of the Bible. The public gardens and the monumental cemetery are also worth a visit.

Between Bologna and Milan and only an hour and a half from Milan is SALSOMAGGIORE, a renowned health resort on account of its thermal springs, change trains at Borgo San Domino and in half-an-hour you are at Salsomaggiore.
